context: [1] Methods: Stool samples were collected from 35 patients with infectious diarrhoea and from six healthy controls. [2] Gaseous compounds were extracted from a headspace using solid phase microextraction and analysed using gas chromatography and mass spectroscopy. [1] Results: Characteristic patterns of volatile gases were found for the main causes of infectious diarrhoea in hospitals. [2] Furan species without indoles indicated Clostridium difficile, ethyl dodecanoate indicated rotavirus, ammonia without ethyl dodecanoate suggested other enteric viruses, and the absence of hydrocarbons and terpenes indicated Campylobacter infection. [1] Diarrhoea due to infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality. [2] In England and Wales, there are approximately 15 000 cases of Clostridium difficile infection per annum (www.PHLS.co.uk). [3] It is estimated that in an average sized district general hospital, 100 cases of C difficile infection can be expected each year with an extra annual cost of Â£400 000 and 2100 lost bed days.
